utterances: So tell me why I'm going to hear the word accountability enough for many lifetimes by the end of this week.
So Hillary Clinton will be going before the House Benghazi committee.
This was created by Republicans to sort of find out who and why these attacks in Benghazi happened and who should be held accountable for them.
That's at least why they say they started their investigation.
Now, in the process of that, a lot of other things have happened.
They found out about her email accounts, and now she's going up there.
And they want to hold her accountable.
They want to see what she knew, what she could have done in regards to the attack, while the same time raising questions about her emails.
Walker actually made it in as an alternate when one of those selected from Delavan couldn't make it.
But Bishop Skrenes says Scott Walker stood out.
He was very poised, very articulate, was well read and very interested in politics and history.
In 1973, Madam Speaker, the United States Supreme Court said the unborn child was not a person under the Constitution.
And we have since witnessed the tragic deaths of over 50 million innocent little baby boys and girls.
Trent Franks of Arizona.
House Republican leaders brought to the floor today a bill to make permanent the annual ban on taxpayer money going to fund abortion services.
Yesterday, House Republicans voted to block mandatory funding of President Obama's health care reform law.
All of this prompting California Democrat Lois Capps to cry...

Instead of moving past divisive social issues and addressing our economic challenges with housing and creating jobs, we are here again today witnessing the Republicans' obsession with reopening the culture wars.
Now, it's not all politics on Capitol Hill right now.
There are serious discussions going on that cross political lines.
How does this affect the war in Afghanistan?
How long should America be there?
And a lot of people in both parties are talking about Pakistan.
Washington Democrat Norm Dicks echoes the prevailing sentiment.
How could nobody in the Pakistani government have known that bin Laden was there?
I'm incredulous by this, and so I think we need to review our relationship - and we give them a lot of money.
Now remember, money is the name of the game in the Capitol.
Every penny the government spends must first be approved by the Congress.

So, while things seem to be going back to normal in Washington, meaning the sniping is back, the killing of Osama bin Laden will resonate through the business and debate of the rest of this year and beyond.
Andrea Seabrook, NPR News, Washington.
Tomorrow John McCain and Barack Obama will put aside partisan politics.
To mark the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks they will appear together at Ground Zero.
The attacks of September 11th have played a powerful role in shaping this country's policies and its politics since that September morning seven years ago.
The legacy of those attacks was particularly influential during the 2004 presidential election.
To find out what role 9/11 is playing in this election, we called John Harwood.
He's a political writer for the New York Times and chief Washington correspondent for CNBC.
Good morning.
Morning, Renee.
Before we go into how this is playing in the current election, remind us, if you would, about the 2004 election.
How big of a role did 9/11 play in the politics then?
I think most analysts look at the decisive voters in the decisive state, in particular the state of Ohio, and said that national security was critical to George W.
Bush's victory.
Those so-called security moms ended up having a choice between some desire for change, but they sided with George W.
Bush because there was a pretty deep identification with the notion that George Bush had been aggressive in trying to protect the country.
How aggressive were the candidates in pushing 9/11 either subliminally or right up front?
Well, in 2004 it was very powerful.
George W.
Bush staged the Republican convention in New York City.
And the images of Bush as reacting in that moment, trying to protect the country, really were the calling card that he brought that election campaign.

National security was the one issue on which he enjoyed a consistent and wide advantage over John Kerry, even though John Kerry had a record of service in Vietnam, which was a significant asset for a Democrat.

I think this year the ability to do that is somewhat diminished because we're not only further away from 9/11, but a little bit of the edge off of the sense of fear and anxiety that Americans have about not just 9/11 but national security in general may have been taken off.
Well, even if it's less influential, how does the whole question of terrorism play to each of the candidates' strengths or to their weaknesses?
Obviously, McCain is highlighting his national security credentials; Obama's trying very hard at this point to make this election about the economy.
So how does the whole memory of 9/11 fit in?
Well, to the extent that it fits in in this election, it helps John McCain.
John McCain is an archetype that Americans have no difficulty understanding.
Somebody who had heroic war service, somebody who is experienced, somebody who displayed in his prisoner of war time in Vietnam steel in his spine.
Now, with Iraq having calmed down to some degree and with the economy having moved to center stage in this election, that shifts a little bit of the formula for how people make their decisions.
There's a lot more desire for change in 2008 than there was in 2004.

So that even though Barack Obama is young, he's new to the scene, he's also an African-American - voters have never had to process that choice before - he benefits from that desire for change on the economy.
And what he's trying to do is minimize the disadvantage he has from Americans who are contemplating who their next commander-in-chief is going to be.
Well, just finally, we began this conversation with this event; that is, McCain and Obama showing up together at Ground Zero, marking the day.
It is non-political, by their description, and yet can it be non-political?
No.
Nothing can be non-political when it features the two nominees in a hotly-contested presidential election.
But you have to remember that the 9/11 attacks were the closest thing to a universal American experience than we've had in a long time.
It's not an accident that George Bush's approval ratings went into the 90s after that event because it was something that the entire country felt very, very deeply.

And so even though they have a tremendous philosophic disagreement on many other issues, John McCain and Barack Obama can go to that site, stand together, and try to tap into those same universal emotions.

And it may help Barack Obama to some degree to be able to stand equal on that stage with John McCain, but by and large, I think, they'll see in these candidates things that draw them together rather than divide them.
Thank you very much for talking with us.
My pleasure.
For the last decade, Americans have had a love affair with SUVs while full-sized sedans have become known as the grandparent car.
In this environment, Toyota is announcing a makeover to its flagship sedan, a car that is still important to Toyota's future.
NPR's Sonari Glinton reports.
All right, it's the big car show here in Detroit, and I'm here to watch the unveiling of one of the most important cars on the road for Toyota.
Now, is it a Formula One race car, a sleek SUV or a super-fast, all-electric, self-driving car - nope, nope and nope.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The all-new 2019 Toyota Avalon you're about to see is more than the sum of its parts.
Now, that's Jack Hollis.
He's in charge of sales at Toyota.
Hollis is selling this vehicle as a sporty, comfortable car with all the tech.
Let's go back to the pitch.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Now, are you ready?
Apple CarPlay is finally standard.
Jack, well done - finally.
Yeah, whatever, whatever.
We know.
We know.
We got it.
Hey, look; it took us a while, folks.
You've all been asking for it.
But it's here.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Now, this is where the Avalon arrives.
They drive it onto the stage.
They play music you can never actually imagine coming out of Avalon speakers.
Then the reporters, analysts and executives storm the stage, including Jake Fisher, head of auto testing at Consumer Reports.
Well, it's interesting that they're packing a lot of technology into the Avalon.
I'm not sure exactly if that's the right market.
When you look at Avalon buyers, you know, I think what's important to them is room and comfort and quietness.
And they didn't talk a lot about that today.
He says Toyota is always cautious but especially with its big-selling cars.
Toyota is always kind of late to the game when it comes to technology, and it's not by accident.
It's because reliability is the No. 1 thing that sells Toyotas, and that's what the people buying Toyotas really care about - not the latest and the greatest, not necessarily any of that stuff.
Fisher says Toyota so dominates the market in the U.S.
it can't really afford to abandon full-size sedans.
This announcement hedges against the future and worries that President Trump might walk out of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Avalon is and has always been Toyota's most American car, and it'll only get more so.
It's completely designed in the U.S.
while other Toyotas have more parts from Mexico or Canada.
After talking with a bunch of analysts, I got a few minutes with Toyota's Jack Hollis.
Is it a tougher market - totally.
But great products still sell.
Great sedans still sell.
I think we'll be putting out a great sedan.
You know that phrase, always be closing?
Well, that's Jack Hollis with his Toyota Avalon.
And I promise.
You get in that car, and you drive it like the way you want to drive it exactly.
And you're going to say, damn, this is good.
And it will exceed your expectations beyond.
And that's what I think any customer gets in this car - that's why I'm selling it that way because when you see a name and you see what it's been before - is not what it's going to be in the future.
Not to be cheeky, but has anyone really ever gotten in a Toyota and been like, damn, this is good?
